title: About
text:
I have a PhD in Neuroscience from the University of Oregon and work as a Workflow Coach for Posit Software.
I tend to find the social lives of non-human animals interesting - thus crows and whales as subject matter.

title: Crow Babies
text:
Available for Purchase Price: $45
Email may.lisa2@gmail.com to inquire.

This summer I watched a juvenile crow beg for food while she was standing on food. The begging went on for days. Man, oh man, it really made me empathize with the parents. And crows do it every year! This a set of four small plates is an ode to parental patience and how hard it is to raise kids. :) They’re little plates - perfect for dunking chicken nuggets in ketchup or holding your rings.

title: Holy Whale
text:
Available for Purchase
Price: $225
Male humpbacks sing for hours, spiraling slowly as their voices carry for miles. This sculpture holds that moment — peaceful, embodied, part of the great chorus.




































Hand sculpted in stoneware for lasting durability, indoors or out. Dimensions: 16” × 8” × 4” (41 × 20 × 10 cm). Two mounting holes allow for easy hanging with nails, screws, or wire.
Stoneware goes through two firings. Here it is after sculpting, before the first fire — and a glimpse of the hollowing process that makes large pieces possible.

title: Buckwheat Mug
text:
Available for Purchase Price: $40














Listen, don’t tell the rest of the mugs, but right out of the kiln this is one of the best mugs of its cohort.
It’s big, it’s strong, it’s a simple mug. It’s not an artist, it might not be interesting with crows or such, but it doesn’t need all that. It’s perfect as it is.
Also obsessed with this buckwheat glaze. On a test tile I was all “boring, when would I ever want that? But for this it’s just right. Look at how it breaks over the carving, it’s eeeeiiii so good.”

title: Doors Mug
text:
Available for Purchase
Price: $50














This is a big, bold mug — [xx] ounces (xx mL) — for someone who wants to commit to their coffee.
The design is based on medieval cathedral doors. I’ve been thinking about doors lately. Points of transition, especially house doors as the transition between what’s internal and private vs. external and public. How we navigate those choices. Doors to different futures, possible choices, other dimensions.
This piece marks a turning point for me: it’s where I started treating mugs as tiny canvases, sketching out a composition based on the space. (Why green? Couldn’t tell you.)
